caption.p: Antigenic drift and antigenic shift in influenza vaccines.

Antigenic drift occurs in all influenza types (A, B, and C) and is caused by small mutations in the antibody binding sites of hemagglutinin, neuraminidase, or both. Antigenic shift occurs only in influenza type A and is caused by exchanges of whole gene segments (often from birds or pigs) in hemagglutinin or neuraminidase that leads to the development of a new subtype of the virus. Antigenic shift is associated with pandemics.
